member.name: T:Rainbow.ObjectFlow.Stateful.IStatefulWorkflow`1
member.summary: A workflow that is able to pause at states and be resumed later.
member.typeparam: The object that will be stepped through the workflow

member.name: M:Rainbow.ObjectFlow.Stateful.IStatefulWorkflow`1.Yield(System.Object)
member.summary: Signal that the workflow should pause here and then resume later at this same point. This can be used to persist the state of the object and resumed later when Continue is called.
member.param: The identifier that describes where the workflow yielded so that it can return to this point later.

member.name: M:Rainbow.ObjectFlow.Stateful.StatefulWorkflow`1.#ctor(System.Object)
member.summary: Creates a workflow that has persistable states and is identified by workflowId.
member.param: Persistable value that represents this workflow.

member.name: M:Rainbow.ObjectFlow.Stateful.StatefulWorkflow`1.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new workflow that has persistable states. Usage of this constructure asserts that an object that might pass through this workflow will pass through only this workflow and no other stateful workflow. Because of this restriction, it is recommended that you use StatefulWorkflow(object) instead.

member.name: M:Rainbow.ObjectFlow.Stateful.StatefulWorkflow`1.Yield(System.Object)
member.summary: Continue the workflow where the given object left off.
member.param: Define the state ID that an object will be given as it leaves this step.

member.name: P:Rainbow.ObjectFlow.Stateful.StatefulWorkflow`1.First
member.summary: The first flow of the workflow

member.name: P:Rainbow.ObjectFlow.Stateful.StatefulWorkflow`1.WorkflowId
member.summary: Gets an identifier that describes the workflow. This can be a string, number, Guid, or any other object that provides a meaningful implementation of the .Equals(object) method.

summary.para: A persistable object that represents where a workflow was left off. By passing one of these objects to a IStatefullWorkflow we can resume the workflow where it was last left off.

The state ID is left as an object but should contain a meaningful implementation of .Equals(object). Therefore, string, int, and Guid are all great choices for state and workflow identifiers. If you choose to make a custom object for this purpose, be sure to provide a meaningful Equals(object) operation.

member.name: M:Rainbow.ObjectFlow.Stateful.IStatefulObject.GetStateId(System.Object)
member.summary: Gets the identifer that represents the object's state. A workflow uses this identifier to restore the state of the object in the
member.param: The identifier for the workflow. If this value is null, this object is expected to either be valid for only a single workflow or should throw a NotSupportedException
member.returns: The state within a workflow that this object is currently in. If the object isn't in a worflow identified by workflowId, this method will return null

member.name: M:Rainbow.ObjectFlow.Stateful.IStatefulObject.SetStateId(System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Gets the identifer that represents the object's state. A workflow uses this identifier to restore the state of the object in the
member.param: The identifier for the workflow. If this value is null, this object is expected to either be valid for only a single workflow or should throw a NotSupportedException
The state identifier for the workflow.
